newsitem.title: USA: IBM, French bank group in digital cash pact.
newsitem.headline: IBM, French bank group in digital cash pact.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp said its software for performing secure financial tranactions over the Internet had been selected by a consortium of leading French financial institutions.
The computer maker said its CommercePoint Software has been chosen by a group including Banque Nationale de Paris, Societe Generale, Credit Lyonnais and France Telecom.
Other backers are Gemplus, a maker of microchip-based "smart cards," a new type of credit card capable of storing digital cash, and credit card consortium Visa International.
IBM said the French financial consortium, known as e-COMM, plans to begin a pilot testing program by mid-1997 in France to develop the standard for high-security payments over the Internet.
The effort combines the international Secure Electronic Transactions (SET) software protocol with smart card technology.
The system would allow consumers to purchase goods and services over the Internet using smart cards from merchants who in turn can authorize and obtain payment from banks.

E-COMM would allow customers to buy low-cost items like a newpaper article, a stock price chart or to rent a software application for one-time use, for example, transactions typically seen as uneconomical using current technology.
The consortium has selected a team of three technology companies, including IBM, Microsoft Corp and SG2, a unit of Societe Generale, to provide elements of the system.
